I'm not very good at tooting my own horn... but I love to paint, and if I could just show you my portfolio... He is baffled. Margaret pulls out a large ARTIST'S PORTFO She opens it, riffling through the pictures...

Margaret waits on a busy corner, a bit dazed peering at the parade of fun-loving Hipsters. Primly, she fixes herself. Margaret turns -- and suddenly grins. Sugar, you made it! You're in North Beach!
Deirdre, look at you!
"Dee-Ann."
"Dee-Ann"?!
Yeah, I know. But I hit this scene... and "Deirdre" just sounded like something my mother would call me. Margaret giggles.

Though... it's hard without her father. I'm not sure we can do this... The thought hangs, and Margaret gets emotional. Teary-eye 5.
Oh stop that. You're better off. Between us, I never liked Frank.
You were a bridesmaid!
Exactly. That's why I couldn't speak up. But if I ever see you wrong off again, I will tell you.
Now come on. Let's have some fun. WIDE - They start WALKING. Dee-Ann gestures.

A Sunday ART SHOW. It's picturesque, amateur ARTISTS displaying their paintings, jewelry, sculpture... The modern stalls are crowded with trendy BOHEMIANS. Abst lines, speckles of color. I'll give you one. Beat -- then she nods, agreeing. She gestures. The little BOY sits. Margaret clips a fresh sheet of pape sharpens her charcoal... and... goes motionless. Studying boy's face. Monet? "Monet"?! Whew -- that's a hell of a compliment. Though, if I may respectfully disagree, I'm more in the tradition of Pissarro. Margaret looks up, distracted. She resumes her work.
C'mon, get closer. Closer! Look at that sunlight coming through the mottled leaves. That's a bold yellow! Curious, Margaret casually peers over...

Holding court in another booth is WALTER KEANE, 40. Walte astonishing: Hugely confident. Charming. Waggishly handsome. And dressed like an "Artist" -- striped turtlen with hands full of brushes. An enchanting bistro. Wine barrels, laughing, twinkly tiv lights. Perfection. Walter flamboyantly enters, escorting Margaret. Instantly, the STAFF ERUPTS in excitement: "Monsieur Keane! Ah, Monsieur Keane is here! Bonsoir!"
Bonsoir, gang! Henri! Sorry I didn't call first. Est-ce que tout va bien?
Je vais bien, merci! Comment allez- vous?

And I don't even have to pay! I'm set because I gave the chef a painting. You know what he said? "Nobody paints Montmartre like Walter Keane!"
Margaret and Walter enjoy an intimate dinner. The wine fl

Best time of my life...

Well you have to experience these things! Grab 'em!!
I wanted to be an artist, so I just went! Studied painting at the Beaux- Arts. Lived in a Left Bank studio. I survived on bread and wine... 10.
You're a romantic.
Damn right! A wistful shrug. He chugs his glass.
Of course, walkin' away from the bourgeois scene wasn't a snap. I had to quit my job. Leave my wife. These choices aren't easy... She stares at her wine.
I've never acted freely. I was the daughter. The wife. The mother...
All my paintings are of Jane, because she's all I know.
You shouldn't knock your work. I'd give an eyetooth to have your talent. Margaret is taken aback. He's absolutely sincere.

You can look into someone and capture them on canvas! You paint people! (he gestures sadly) I can only paint -- things. My street scenes are charming... but at the end of the day, it's just a collection of sidewalks and buildings. Walter goes silent. He has revealed his fears.
She doesn't know what to say. Gently, she takes his hand.
Walter, I'd bet you could paint anything.
Whew... Baby, when you look at me like that, I could fall hard. Margaret gulps. Afraid to talk. 11.
This is moving fast. You're my first date in a long time... Neither of them speaks. The tension builds -- There is a spark between them...

Jane! Don't bother Mr. Keane. You know creativity has to well up from the inside...

I believe things can be seen in eyes. They're the windows of the soul -- 12.

When I was little, I had surgery that left me deaf for a period. I couldn't hear, so I found myself staring... Relying on people's eyes... She smiles shyly. Understanding, he smiles back. Then --

All I ever wanted was to support myself as an artist...
I tried to make a clean break, but couldn't cut it. I'm just a goddam Sunday painter. An amateur. Margaret looks at him, touched by his vulnerability.

Margaret, I'm on my knee! C'mon, whatdya say? Let's get married! We can be in Hawaii by the weekend.

Walter, I'm crazy about you... but I'm overwhelmed. Why would we go to Hawaii?!
Because you're a princess... and you deserve to get married in paradise.

I'm not naive. (beat; she laughs) Well, I am naive. But I know the man I'm marrying. Walter can act rash... but he's a good provider. And he's wonderful with Jane.

Look -- we're both looking for a fresh start. I'm a divorcee with a child. Walter is a blessing. Dee-Ann bites her tongue. The WAITER brings over the chec Sitting on it are TWO FORTUNE COOKIES. Hm. "You are on the threshold of untold success."

A Modish, happening gallery. The white walls are hung wit ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONISM: Slashing angles of color, painted rags and glued bolts. On the floor is SCULPTURE made from wood and wire. Not -- "art"??

Yeah.
Well you're a hell of a painter. Walter squints, confused, then beams. Joy! Happiness bursting like a little child.

You're right! I know. But... I was already in a bad place. I'd had a couple... and earlier...
I let some guy think I painted your Big Eye. Beat. Margaret is stupefied.
I don't understand. Why would you do such a thing?!

He shrugs feebly. She frowns.

Can you believe this? We're sold out, and I don't even have a headliner!!
Hell, it's a Monday! Walter blinks, lost. Banducci explains.
Dope, we made the front page!! People are here, cause they wanna see the sappy paintings that made grown men fight!! A moment of discombobulation... until -- Walter slowly gr
The two men suddenly tumble into view, SCREAMING.

I'll see you in COURT, you son of a bitch! I'm suing you for assault! Slander! False arrest!! Banducci storms away. Walter shudders, "upset." CUSTOMERS peer at him... then a the paintings. Curious, they migrate that way... 27.

Walter glances sideways. Gauging their reactions... Until -- a swinging middle-aged guy in horn rims and a su lopes up. DICK NOLAN: A man who hides his bored emptiness under a veneer of booze and broads. Dick leans in.
Yes sir! Whew. That was quite a load of horseshit you gents were layin' out there.
Dick Nolan. The Examiner. Walter freezes up. Until -- Dick grins conspiratorially.
Hey pal, don't lose any sleep. I eat this stuff with a spoon! It gives me something to type about, in my column.
(he laughs, relieved) I thought you only did celebrities.
Well, Banducci's famous -- and you hit him! So you're a celebrity, once- removed.
Buy me a drink?
Huh? Uh, sure -- Dick smoothly drags him to the bar. Dick waves the barten
Gary! I'll have a Ward Eight, in a frosted high boy. My friend'll have the same. (he beams, then turns) So! Walter, tell me about your work --
Well, when I was in Paris...
Jesus, not those! I mean the little hobo kids. What?! Walter frowns, peeved. He considers this indignity then decides to stomach it. He smiles fakely, effusively.
What do you wanna know...?!
Margaret is asleep. Suddenly Walter bursts in, drunk and jocular. He FLIPS on the lights.
Ding-a-ling! Wake up, we're a HIT! Margaret rolls over, groggy. Walter jumps on the bed, grinning. He tosses her a HANDFUL OF MONEY.
What a night! I sold out all your Big Eyes!! She rubs her eyes, amazed.
There must be two-hundred dollars...
They adore you! Cause of that article, the joint was PACKED. And then, a famous journalist showed up, and -- I need more paintings! Now! He hungrily KISSES her. She laughs.
Walter, they take at least a week. There's layering, shading --
Of course! But, this is opportunity! Ah, we're gonna make a crackerjack team: Me schmoozing up the club, while you're back here, doing what you love! She stares at him -- then smiles. MUSIC...
Margaret happily paints away. At peace, lost in her art..
Walter sells Big Eyes. Shoving cash into a cigar box.
Margaret works, HUMMING serenely. On the easel is a half- finished blonde girl in a blue dress. 29.
Walter buys a new suit. A TAILOR measures him.

Margaret finishes painting a sad boy, using a fine brush add a watery rim to his eyes. Magically, this detail brin the picture to life. She's pleased. Margaret signs "KEANE." There are two finished canvases, sad little girl and boy. Margaret smiles, her heart swell She loves them. Then, she looks about. Nobody is there to share the moment. Hm. She thinks -- then picks up the PHONE. She dials.
Mrs. Cava, I'm sorry to bother you so late... but would you mind watching Jane?
Margaret rides in the back seat, smiling, her gaze farawa She proudly hugs the bundled paintings to her chest.
The club is pounding. Margaret enters the throng, carryin her work. She looks up -- and has her breath taken away.

head_text.subj: ENTIRE CLUB, EVERY WALL, IS NOW HUNG WITH KEANE PAINTINGS

text: Whoa...! Pure joy envelops her. Then -- she gets jostled. Margaret notices Walter holding court with some GROUPIES. She approaches, unnoticed:
...yeah, eyes are powerful. A poet said they're the windows of the soul. Margaret smiles, touched. She comes closer....
They hold so much feeling.
You got it! That's why I paint 'em so big.
I've always done it that way.
She GASPS, stunned. The room starts spinning. 30.
If you like this style, I'm working on a few new pieces. I've got a little blonde girl in a blue dress that'll tear your heart out.
Her face goes ashen. Dizzy, she clutches for support. What to do?? Overcome, she shrinks away... disappearing.. ending up alone in a corner. She cowers, childlike.
Walter LAUGHS at a joke, then backslaps the group. He jovially strides away... passing by Margaret... when --
Walter...? He spins -- shocked at her presence.
Baby!
Hey, uh, what are you doing here? I
Why are you lying? For once, Walter has no answer. She bores in, emotions racing. Confused. Hurt.
You're taking credit for something that isn't yours. He looks ill. Wheels spinning, looking for an out --
I was... trying to close the deal --
Those children are part of my being!
I'm just a salesman! You know, buyers pay more if they meet the painter --
They couldn't meet me, because you told me to stay home!! 31.
Shh, QUIET! He grabs her, pulling her behind a curtain. He's desperat
Don't blow this! Look, we're makin' money! Your pocket, my pocket? What's the difference?!
You take this so lightly --
Not all all! But it's not about ego! You wanna say you did the street scenes? Fine! I don't care! Say a monkey painted it! She breaks into tears, sobbing.
I'm glad you can dash off your pieces without any emotional connection...!
Ah, honey! I just wanna share them with the world!
Would you rather have your children piled in a closet... or hanging in someone's living room? Silence. Then -- FLASH! FLASH! FLASH! Walter turns. And -- his eyes pop, astonished.

Is an incredible sight. Like a moment from "La Dolce Vita fabulously dressed ITALIAN MAN with THREE BLONDES floats the stairs, into the club. Cameras FLASH. Walter gapes, transfixed. He grabs Banducci.
Hey. Who is that remarkably handsome and confident man?
That's Dino Olivetti -- as in Olivetti typewriters.
Don't even try, Walter. He doesn't speak a lick of English. Walter stares hungrily.

glides into the club -- a vision of perfection with his s hair and sunglasses. He approaches closer, closer... when gets distracted. By one of Margaret's Big Eye PAINTINGS. Walter gasps. He nudges Margaret. Olivetti peers at the artwork. Intrigued. Then -- excited He starts gesturing and yapping in ITALIAN. The Blondes s back. Everyone is getting worked-up. The big-bosomed Blonde turns to Walter.
Mr. Olivetti is enchanted with the painting. He would like to know... who is the artist?

The moment of truth. Margaret opens her mouth... and no s comes out. She clenches up. Stomach tight. Mute. Walter gives her a second -- tick tock tick tock. Then -- leaps into Opportunity. He SMACKS his hands.
I am! Walter swoops over and grabs Olivetti in a hearty clasp.
It's a delight to meet you, Signore! Buon giorno! Have you been an art lover for long..? We move in tight on MARGARET, as the SOUND DIALS DOWN.

I call that piece "The Waif." Isn't it striking? With its juxtaposition of girl, cat, and stairs... and its almost Flemish use of underpigment... The SOUND dims... then goes SILENT. Margaret stares in shock, unmoving. Time seems to stop. She is frozen in grief. Until -- 33.
Baby! Baby! Can you believe it?!!
Time has passed. Walter happily clutches Margaret.
We made five grand!! Five THOUSAND dollars...!!!
And that wasn't even one of your good ones! Margaret blinks, lost. In the b.g., Olivetti holds the painting, now wrapped-up newspaper and twine. A pleased customer. Margaret's face darkens.
Don't you mean... one of your good ones?

No. No no! One of -- OUR good ones. (the spirit of generosity, he hands her a CHECK) Look at those zeroes! We've hit the big time! We are now hanging in the collection of Italian industrialist Dino Olivetti! With his patronage comes credibility! And with credibility comes RESPECT! Margaret stares at the check in her hands. At all the zer
What about... honesty?
Aw c'mon! The paintings say "Keane"! I'm Keane, you're Keane. From now on, we are one and the same. Walter pulls her tight. She doesn't resist.
Upbeat MUSIC. Walter frantically tosses all the BROCHURES him and Margaret into a FIREPLACE. They burn to ash.
We ZOOM into Dick Nolan's SOCIETY COLUMN. Under a caricat of Dick is a highlighted ITEM. We hear TYPING:
"What exactly is local painter Walter Keane up to? My spies tell me a big announcement is forthcoming...!"
Walter proudly hands a painting to the confused-looking M
On behalf of the children of the world, we present this painting to Mayor Christopher!
Walter thrusts a painted Ballerina at a SOVIET DIPLOMAT.
In the interest of peace through culture, we donate this painting to the people of Russia!
Dick whispers into a phone.
The Purple Onion. 9:30. Joan Crawford has a dinner reservation.
JOAN CRAWFORD is eating with friends. Suddenly Walter lun into view, startling her. He lugs a painting.
Miss Crawford! In recognition of your cinematic craft, we bestow this painting, "The Lion and the Child"!
Margaret paints. Walter beams. 35.
Joan said "Marvelous"! MARVELOUS! That's worth more than 1000 critics! (he CLAPS his hands) Hey, maybe she'll come to our opening.
But... isn't it strange? Artists get shown. They don't build their own galleries.
Says who?! Like John Q. Public cares? He's FED UP with abstract neoformalism! She responds -- but he sexily puts his finger to her mout

He digs real art. Your art! It's beautiful. You're beautiful... Walter starts rubbing against her, dancing sensually. She laughs, embarrassed, her wet paint brushes smearing his c She relents and relaxes. They dance around...

In the shadows, POSTERS of "The Waif" get glued up. Under woeful face, it says "KEANE GALLERY 494 Broadway." We WID as Walter, Margaret and Jane hastily slap up the posters. They carry glue buckets and a ladder.
Ruben's gonna choke when he sees this! Little Jane tiredly glues another poster. She yawns.
I remember when Momma painted that. Huh? Suddenly, Margaret freezes. She hadn't anticipated this. Margaret looks to Walter. He stares back, waiting.
Are you -- sure? That was a long time ago.
Sure I'm sure! It was in our old apartment, and you had me sit on a stool in the kitchen -- 36.
No, dear, I'm afraid you're confused. I painted that one --
No, Mother did! Look! I'm wearing my blue dress.
L-lots of girls have that dress... Margaret trails off, sickened. Not knowing how to lie. Walter takes charge. He kneels, then smiles gently at Jan
You have a good eye, sweetie. I painted it, but I was trying to mimic your mother's style. You know, the style she USED to paint in.
A loooooong pause. She examines the print. Then... she no
Well you did a really good job.

CU on the Waif. We widen, revealing the ENTIRE WORLD has hijacked, blanketed by THE POSTERS. People gape -- astoni and captivated. Disconnected from it all, strolling alone, is Margaret. S is burdened by her own thoughts. Regretful... Across the street, she sees a GOTHIC CHURCH. She stares u awed by the beauty. It's Catholic imagery in all its glor Saints... Jesus... Mary... Suddenly -- the bells RING. Hm. Margaret takes a step...
Margaret tentatively enters and kneels. Beat -- then the grille OPENS. She reacts, discomposed.
Hello. I've -- never really done this before. I'm not sure how you...
I was raised Methodist. If it's a problem, I can go -- 37.
She starts to stand. The Priest blurts out.
No, no! Please. We don't chase people away.
What is troubling you? Margaret takes a breath.
I lied to my child. Pause.
Why would you do that?
My husband... he pressured me into doing it.
I've never lied to her before. I'm not that kind of person. Beat.
Is your husband that kind of person?
Ummm, no. I don't think of him that way. I mean, he likes to tell stories... maybe he exaggerates a little... but he's a good man.
He takes care of us. He wants to make enough money to buy our family a house...
But what of the child? Will this lie bring harm to her?
"Harm"?? Oh! Not at all.
I'm just looking for answers... The Priest considers this.
Well, the modern world is a complicated place.
Occasionally, children need to be sheltered from certain truths.
N-no. That's not what --
It sounds like your husband is trying to make the best of an imperfect situation.
You were raised Christian, so you know what we are taught: The man is head of the household.
Perhaps you should trust his judgment.

Opening night! The gallery is packed with the IN CROWD: R and drinking. The space is cool -- the walls bright white the art hanging under spotlights. JAZZ plays on the stere At one painting, a HIPSTER COUPLE stares at the image of sorrowful girl holding an armful of poodle puppies.
I think it's creepy, maudlin and amateurish.

Exactly. I love it. We move in tight on the painting. Underneath is a tag: "BEDTIME, by WALTER KEANE. Oil on canvas." We drift along, to another painting: "CALICO CAT, by WALT KEANE." Then, another: "IN THE GARDEN, by WALTER KEANE." Every painting is now by Walter Keane. We move along... finding the Tipsy Man chatting up Dick.
We got in early. We own three.

Thanks, doll. He tosses his empty to a PASSING LADY. We reveal the wait is... Margaret. She carries a tray of pigs-in-a-blanket. Margaret looks shell-shocked -- faking a happy party face A burst of LAUGHTER. Margaret turns. 39.
Walter and a group ROAR at a joke. A SEXY GIRL hands Walt one of the promo posters. He beams and lays it across her back... hugging her waist to "steady" himself as he signs
She frowns. Dee-Ann slides into view, slurping champagne.
Hey, baby! Killer party! It's a hap- pen-ing...! So, where's your stuff?
Oh. Um, we decided that this would be Walter's show --
Oh "we" did?? And why would "we" do that??
Well... he's more established.
Please! Is that you talking, or did you just turn into a little felt puppet with someone's hand up your ass? Margaret is befuddled. Dee-Ann scopes out the artwork.
It's strange... Walter doesn't strike me as the cute hungry kitten type... Margaret grimaces.
Thanks for coming. Margaret grabs a drink and hurries away. Dee-Ann stands there, irked. Margaret cuts over to Walter. We MOVE IN TIGHT ON THE COU He grins and grabs her.
Ah, my sweet! Are you enjoying the scene? (he gives her a kiss)
Give a hand to my beautiful wife. Without her, none of tonight would be possible! The crowd APPLAUDS politely, condescendingly. Margaret smiles strangely. The Tipsy Man leans in.
Your husband's quite a talent.
Do you paint, too? Margaret freezes up, terribly awkward.
I don't... know.
A NOSY GUY corners him in front of a painted child.
I'm curious about your technique. How long did that piece take to execute?
That? Oh, wow. Probably... months. First the thinking, the sketching, and then time with just me and the oils.
"Oils"? But isn't that acrylic...? Huh? Walter glances at the painting, startled.
Oh --! You mean that painting! Uhh, sorry! It's like a jumble of ideas, rattling around in my brain! Beat.
So where do you get your ideas?
What do you mean?
I mean -- (confused at this confusion) Why are they... images of children? Yikes. Walter starts to sweat. He didn't think this throu 41.
Well, er, I've just always loved kids. Though mostly I was influenced by my darling daughter... An odd beat.
I remember when she was a baby... Walter gets a far-off look.

Yeah. Cute little thing. I'd stare into those big orbs. Sometimes I'd get out my Brownie and snap a photo... but... that's not subjective. You know? It doesn't capture your feelings. So that's when I started painting her... We hold on Walter, unsure where reality begins and ends..
CU on a fuzzy TV SCREEN: A PRIGGISH MAN is griping. The screen is captioned "JOHN CANADAY, NY TIMES ART CRITIC"

Keane's work is completely without distinction. He is not a member of the Society of Western Artists. He has won no awards. He's only noteworthy for his appearances in a certain newspaper's gossip column!
Mr. Keane is why society NEEDS critics! To protect them from such atrocities! Walter gapes at the TV, outraged. He suddenly grabs a PHO
Jane is BANGING on a closed door.
Mom! I wanna come in.
Uhh, you can't. Mommy's busy.
(she BANGS again) Let me in! What are you doing in there? Why's the door always locked? 42.
Walter enters -- and reacts. He glides over to the girl.
Janie, sweetie, you need to respect your mother's privacy. Sometimes grownups need alone time.

Is that the ice cream truck? Why don't you go get yourself a fudgesicle? Walter tosses her a dime. She peers warily, then leaves. He waits a beat -- then pulls out a KEY. Walter discreetl unlocks the painting room.

It's a factory. Big Eyes are everywhere. Margaret frenzie works, surrounded by half-done canvases, solvents, easels She's in a bathrobe -- a cigarette hanging from her lips. Startled, she looks up to see Walter. He gazes at all the art. At the bulbous faces, eyes water and submissive, trapped in muddy yellows and dire browns. then... Walter grins broadly.
Whew! Out of this world...!
I dunno. I'm not really comfortable with this. Jane and I used to be so close... but -- now...
Ah, Jane's grand! She's eating ice cream! She has new shoes. She has a college fund. Beat.
Maybe I'm lightheaded from the turpentine. I've been in here all day.
Well I don't want you feeling like a prisoner. Take a break! Walter glances at one PAINTING -- then does a take.
It's a child in a rusty alley, staring, aching for compas And, starting to cry. A single tear streams down her chee 43.
Is that a tear...? You've gone deep! Margaret bites her fingers, worried.
Do you -- like it?
I love it! ...How'd you get the eyes so lifelike? Is it the highlights?
No. The secret is the shadow. I shadowed the eyelid. Margaret smiles shyly. Walter smiles back, full of warmth He takes her face in his hands.
I owe you an apology. I was initially dismissive of your kids, those emotion- wrenching blobs of humanity... but they have a real strength.
Is that your best version of sincerity?
I'm trying! Ah, you know me. See -- this is why I need your help! I want to go on tv, to defend our art.
You're going to be on television?!
Yes! But... what will I say??
Meaning -- what compels me... to paint... these paintings?? A bizarre pause. The two of them look around the room. At all the Big Eyes peering down at them.
Maybe you have an unhealthy obsession with little girls.
Cute. 44.
I guess you've painted yourself into a corner.
Funny! Keep 'em coming! You're a regular Steve Allen. You want heat this winter? Help me out!
Walter... art is personal. Walter picks up a picture of TWO LITTLE GIRLS IN TUTUS. H stares, perplexed.
What would make a grown man paint a picture like this?! No answer. He thinks of stories, wheels spinning.
I grew up, surrounded by six sisters.
I grew up in an orphanage?
I grew up... in a world where adults had vanished, and children and kittens ran wild over the desolate landscape! Margaret smiles.
What about your Paris street scenes? Why do you paint those?
Well, because... I lived it! I experienced it!

(calling his bluff) And was it really all sun-dappled streets and flower vendors? Huh? Walter stares off at the Waifs. They peer out from broken windows... chain-link fences... And then -- he gets it.
Well -- NO! Of course not. It was after the War. There was destruction everywhere...
I traveled the Continent. The ravages were horrifying...
Walter is on TV, on a LOCAL PUBLIC AFFAIRS SHOW. He's coa with makeup, sitting rigidly, fingers gripping his chair.

My psyche was scarred in my art student days. Nothing in my life has ever made such an impact as the sight of the children: War-wracked innocents, without homes, without parents, fighting over garbage... He sits in a half-circle of PROPER WOMEN, who are spellbo

Goaded by a frantic despair, I sketched these dirty, ragged little victims... with their bruised minds and bodies, their matted hair and runny noses. There my life as a painter began in earnest. Walter sadly looks up to the HOST. The man is shellshocked. Mute. Walter waits, then sighs.

The insane, inhuman cruelty inflicted upon these children cut deeply into my being. From that moment on, I painted the lost children with the eyes. Those eyes that forever retained their haunting quality. The ladies are stricken. A few dab their eyes.
Keane posters get RIPPED off a wall. RIPPED off a mailbox. PULLED off a construction site!
Walter strides along, a bounce to his step. He reaches th gallery -- then stops, dumbfounded. It's PACKED with PEOP Not rich, but regular folks, gawking at the art. 46.

Wow. A sweet moment... then some TOURISTS see Walter and happily accost him: "Walter Keane!" "Mr. Keane!" They thr papers and POSTERS at him to autograph. Walter grins and scribbles his signature. Glancing over t shoulders, he sees Ruben down the block, standing outside own gallery. Gaping in disbelief. Walter chuckles... then flips him off. Ruben's face falls
Walter pushes through, shaking hands, greeting the CUSTOM
Good afternoon! Delighted! (he reaches the SEXY BLONDE CLERK and pinches her ass) How many sales today?
"Sales?" None with this crowd. Walter's smile drops, surprised.

These people are looky-loos! They can't afford the paintings. But we gave away a heap of posters! Huh? Walter peers, baffled. Suddenly -- a loud FRWWIPPPP! Walter whirls, startled. Outside, two GIRLS tear a big po off the front window. Walter's eyes widen. Slowly, he turns back. At the counte FOLKS and KIDS are grabbing free posters from a box. Walter stares. Processing this. And then... being struck an idea of absolute genius...
Walter is on the telephone, peering through the doorway. Hiding from the customers. Spying. WHISPERING.

It's the craziest thing. I started charging for the posters! First a nickel... then a dime. (struggling to whisper) YES, Maggie! It's cuckoo! So it got me thinkin': Would you rather sell a $500 painting, or a million cheaply- reproduced posters?! (he LAUGHS, exultant)
See, folks don't care if it's a copy. They just want art that touches them!

And then... we could sell it anywhere!! EVERYWHERE! 60's-style MADISON AVENUE GRAPHICS: A still of a HARDWARE STORE. Mops, light bulbs, then -- BING! -- framed KEANES. A PHARMACY. Aspirin, candy bars -- BING! -- framed KEANES A GAS STATION. Tires, motor oil, and -- BING! -- KEANES.

An aisle of Sundries: Plastic toys, beach balls... Waifs. sign says "WE HAVE KEANE!" Around the corner, Margaret shuffles along, listlessly bu banalities: Cereal. Soap. She turns the cart... and runs into her wall of teary-eyed kids. Margaret peers, muddled. Then she turns away -- to a RACK OF PAPERBACKS. They offe fast hope, inspiration. Margaret seems disconnected. She runs her hand down the options... a book of Numerology... book on Judaism... an Edgar Cayce prophecies manual... AT THE REGISTER - Margaret gazes up. The CASHIER is a sad Beatnik Girl. In a haze, Margaret notices the whole marke full of LONELY WOMEN: One LADY is her doppelganger -- same age, blonde, grippin cart. Next aisle over, a MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN stares into sp Nearby, a YOUNG MOM wrangles her children. We shift to Margaret. Face gaunt. Eyes empty. Troubled...

Curtains drawn, Margaret frantically SKETCHES. She's cabi feverish. In her robe. Hair dirty. And -- up to something These sketches aren't squat children with round eyes. The different: Figures with long lines. Margaret frowns and rips the paper. She tries again! Anot angular figure -- straight fingers... no! Again! A woman... reclining. Then an indication of a face A slash... and then -- two small almond shapes for eyes. 48.
Hmm. Margaret's face brightens. She likes it.

Margaret rabidly paints. Spurting globs of color. The wom is blonde, almond eyes cool, lips curled with mystery... Margaret glances in a mirror. It's a self-portrait. It's Margaret, aloof. Alone at a table. Suddenly the door opens. Margaret GASPS, startled, and sp the canvas away. Walter barges in, dressed like a million He HALTS -- making a sour face.
Whew! Something smells in here. You should open a window. Margaret blinks, a bit dazed.
What time is it?
I dunno. 6:30, 7? ...Didn't Janie get dinner? Margaret shrugs. Walter leans in.
When's the last time you washed your hair?
I've been... busy.
(he notices the turned canvas; he's intrigued) What do you got back there? Lemme see.
No --! It's just... something I'm working on. It's not for the world. Walter gives her a funny look.
"The world"? Baby, it's me! (stepping forward, a bit
I'm your number one fan.
No, please! Walter, it's -- personal. 49.

But we're husband and wife. We shouldn't have secrets... Margaret gulps, fretting. Finally, without options -- she flips over the canvas of the lonely blonde. And -- Walter is taken aback. His eyebrows raise, shocked Margaret bites her lip. Will he go ballistic?
He leans right up to the painting. His expression is inscrutable. Studying the technique. We have no idea what his emotion is.
It's a completely different style.
Yes it is.
It looks like you.
It's a self-portrait. Beat.
How am I gonna explain that? She shifts about.
I thought... maybe... I could sign it myself. Hmm. Walter's eyes narrow.
That seems a bit confusing. "Keane" means me.
Yes, I know... but... when people ask me if I paint, I don't know what to answer! I just want the pride of being able to say -- that's mine. Walter's wheels are ratcheting. 50.
Who'd you tell about the Big Eyes?
Nobody!
Was Dee-Ann here?! Did Dee-Ann see this painting?!
No! NOBODY saw it!
You tell anybody, the empire COLLAPSES! Do you wanna give back the money? We've committed FRAUD!
I KNOW! My God! I live with this every minute of my life!
Janie used to have a mother who painted. Now what's she think?! I lock myself in this room ten hours a day... and then you walk out with finished paintings! He scowls, offended.
Janie thinks I'm in here, painting.
C'mon! You haven't picked up a brush in months! (starting to sob) We used to paint together! Easels next to each other, side-by-side --
That was the honeymoon period! Margaret breaks into tears. Walter tenses.
Jesus, you're so fragile.
I've kept my end of the bargain! I've never told! (she SOBS harder) Please! Just let me have this! Walter recoils, unable to take this. He relents. 51.

Another PHOTO OP, but big: A CAMERA CREW rushes about. Li get set-up. Walter, Margaret, and Jane work at easels. Walter dabs at a Big Eye. Margaret works on a sad, long-n blonde. Jane paints a goofy flower, like any child. Dick Nolan takes notes.
So you're now called "The Painting Keanes"?
Yep! Walter and his girls! With galleries in three cities!
I had no idea Margaret painted.
Yeah, we don't talk about it. Sadly, people don't buy lady art.
What about Georgia O'Keefe? Dick shakes his EMPTY GLASS, distracted. Walter points.
The bar's over there. Dick goes to get a refill. Walter shoots Margaret a look.
Yeah, Margaret's a superb artist, in her own way. I even steal a few tips from her, now and then!
Behind every great man is a great woman.
True true. So Margaret, where do you get your ideas?
(a bit tentative) Oh... from the world around me. And I love Modigliani's use of line.
ModiWHAT? The Italian joint? 52.
Oh, for Christ's sake, Margaret! Dick writes a gossip column --
Let's stick to the family angle. Get a gander at little Janie over there! Walter steers Dick to Jane, cute at her little child's ea
What a talent! Look at these Keanes! If you cut open our veins, we bleed oil! Er -- turpentine.
Uh, Dick, you know what I'm goin' for. Make it sound good. DING-DONG! It's the doorbell. Everyone turns.
Who's that?
Ah! A little treat! The fourth member of the Painting Keanes! Margaret and Jane turn, confused. Walter whips open
Revealing LILY, 10, a quiet girl in bobbed hair. She hold little overnight bag. A Buick HONKS, and Walter waves as it drives away. Walter stares at the girl, then puts on big hammy airs.
Lily, honey, how are you?! He gives her a giant hug. She responds stiffly -- a girl doesn't see her father too often.
I'm fine, Dad. I lost a tooth.
Really? Did you get in a fight?
No. It fell out!
They gape in bewilderment. Who the hell is this girl 53.
Walter admires Lily's mouth.
Well is the tooth fairy somethin' I gotta deal with, or did your mother already handle it?
She handled it.
Good! Good good! Well, just go throw your stuff in the kids' room, then you can come join the fun! Lily toddles out.
Margaret and Jane are speechless. Walter acts like nothing bizarre has happened. Dick eyeballs all this with major curiosity.
Walter... you never told me you had another daughter.
Didn't I? Sure. Lil's from my first marriage. Margaret struggles to hold her rage. Disoriented...
Walter?
Walter! We need to speak. Margaret gestures: Get in the kitchen! He nods and follow
Margaret shuts the door, then spins on him.
What is going on here
That's Lily. I'm sure I mentioned her --
No you didn't. 54.
Margaret peers at him. How much can she trust?
Did she just move in??
No! Her mom's just going to Vegas for the weekend.
I'm supposed to have her once a month, but I don't make her mom enforce it.
Her head is spinning.
How can you keep something so big a secret???
He starts to answer... then gives her a look: You are kid Walter squirms defensively.
She's a sweet girl.
I'm sure she is.
I put up with your daughter. I never said a peep. Margaret's jaw drops.
I'm gonna pretend you didn't say that.
I'm sorry. Sorry! Please... let's just try to get through this.
Jane's room, cute with stuffed animals and troll dolls. Lily is in the corner, awkwardly unpacking her bag. Tryin not to impose on Jane's space. The girls peer at each oth
Dad told me you had a bunk bed. 55.
Jane shakes her head. She feels bad.
Take the bed. I can sleep on the
No, that's not fair! The floor's fine for me. Jane smiles nervously. She stares at this new girl.
Do you live far away?
I guess... about a twenty minute drive.
"Twenty minutes"?! That's close! Jane blinks, confused.
But you never see Walter?
No, I see him all the time! He comes up and visits every week. Jane is taken aback. Lily sees this.
Doesn't he talk about me?
Huh? Uh... sure. I guess a little. Jane thinks, fretting.
Does he talk about me?
Uh... yeah. Sometimes.
So what's your mom like?
She's pretty. She drives a Buick. She cries a lot. 56.
Yeah, mine's the same.
Except she drives a Packard. Lily nods. Jane lowers her voice naughtily.

I have some peanut butter hidden in my sock drawer. Do you wanna eat it? Lily smiles: Sure. Jane opens a drawer and removes a jar Skippy. The two girls sit on the floor, happily eating th peanut butter with their fingers.
Klieg lights streak the sky! A crazed CROWD is packed INS A big sign announces: "NOW APPEARING: AMERICA'S FIRST FAM OF ART - 'We paint truth and emotion.'"
The place is filled with Big Eyes. Waifs waifs waifs! Cas registers RING. Money changes hands. "Sold" stickers go u Walter works the room.

Yeah, Walter Keane and Gauguin have a lot in common. They both walked away from successful careers to travel the globe, live on a boat... We move... finding Margaret alone in a small ANNEX. It displays a few of her sad blondes, alongside Jane and Lil paintings of flowers and Mr. Potato-Head. Margaret sits, seeming like an adult at the children's table. An urbane RICH MAN glides by... and is taken with one of Margaret's nubile blondes. He gazes at the lounging figur Margaret sits up. Alert, pleased with his interest. She tingles. Then, happily excited, unable to hold it in:
I painted it!
Really?
It's very evocative. ...Sensual... He smiles flirtatiously. She smiles shyly and shrugs. 57.
He steps forward -- then peers closer at the painting. Th SIGNATURE is a feminine scroll: "MDH Keane"
"MDH"? You're so... mysterioso.
Yes, we don't use my name, since people don't take women's art seriously.
"MDH" are my initials. And more! I'm interested in numerology... and as you know, seven is a very good number.
Er... seven?

Luckily, my maiden name is Margaret Doris Hawkins! "M" is the 13th letter of the alphabet, "D" is 4, "H" 8! If you add up 1 and 3 in 13, that gives you 4, making 4 plus 4 plus 8 equals 16, then 1 plus 6 equals seven! The man's head is spinning. He's lost all interest. Across the room, Walter sees this debacle. He marches ove

Psst! Maggie! Can I have a second? (he PULLS HER ASIDE) Good grief! What the hell are you babbling about?! Long division?? Could you please help the world and shut your mouth? You want just one number in his head: The sales price! Her face drops, hurt. Acquiescing.
Two SNOBBY ARTISTS smirk and GROAN at this scene.
Two nuts that fell from the same tree! It's insufferable. Why are we starving, while they print money?
Because that nut's a genius! He sells paintings! Then he sells pictures of the paintings! Then he sells postcards of pictures of the paintings. 58.
They stare bitterly. Then, a terrible, shameful idea form
I'll bet I could bang one out in ten minutes.
It wouldn't have the dopey sincerity.
The customers won't notice... They peer sheepishly at each other...

Ruben is walking past -- then stops, pained. A window dis of Keane Big Eyes shares space with paintings of CUTESY KITTENS lapping up milk. We WIDEN, revealing a whole wall of rip-offs! All with od anonymous signatures: "Gig." "Eve." "Igor." A cavalcade o
AS HOBOS... PLAYING IN PAJAMAS. But these children aren't sad. They're just... blank. Ruben gasps at the dead-eyed pictures.
Christ. It's a movement.
"The Tonight Show" opening CREDITS:

It's "The Tonight Show!" With guests Jerry Lewis, the Everly Brothers, artists Walter and Margaret Keane -- The CHANNEL CHANGES: A children's toy commercial (STOCK). tear-streaked, crying plastic DOLL, a flagrant Waif rip-o
She's "Little Miss No Name," the doll with the tear. From Hasbro. The CHANNEL CHANGES: Spanish TELEVISION. A Keane painting gets hung in Madrid's National Museum of Contemporary Art

The Margaret sweatshop is going full-blast. Canvases are everywhere: Melancholy MDH ladies. Woeful Keane kids. Eve portrait of Natalie Wood, copied from a photo. Margaret d a tiny brush, quickly detailing the tear on a child's che when the doorbell CHIMES. Hm? Margaret puts down her brush, wipes her hands, then hurries out. She opens the door... REVEALING THAT WE'RE I DIFFERENT HOUSE. A GIANT, PHENOMENAL 1960s EXTRAVAGANZA.

Margaret runs across the marble floors, past the swooping Modern lines of a California ranch... all-white furniture kidney-shaped pool glistening blue outside the glass... a TOY POODLE barking at the door.
Rembrandt, shush! In the foyer, Margaret opens the front door. And standing there is Dee-Ann. Dazzled. She laughs with surprise.
My God! I thought I misread the address.
Yeah. That driveway is long. (she giggles, embarrassed) Honestly, I can't believe I live here. Dee-Ann glides in -- then freezes, agape.
Whoa.
I know! Two acres, a pool, five
Though I thought that was excessive, since there's only three of us here.
Three? I thought there were four.
What?
Oh -- you mean Lily! No, she doesn't really live with us. That was just in the articles. 60.
Crazy. A fake daughter... Dee-Ann's eyes take it all in. Astonished.
It's been so long since I've seen you.
I know. North Beach is 30 miles, but it might as well be 300...
You're probably busy, hanging out with your new rich buddies.
"Kim Novak."
Oh, please! She's Walter's friend. (a quiet shrug) He brings people by... the Beach Boys were here. But, it's pretty isolated. Dee-Ann goes silent. Margaret seems dwarfed by the house.
Jane has nice friends. Sometimes I pick them up at the junior high, and we all get pizza.
But she's busy... Are you hungry?
I'm thirsty.
Good! I'll whip us up two gin fizzes. Margaret forces a smile and scurries behind a giant curve bar. She pulls out ingredients: Gin, lemon juice, soda...
When we moved in, I thought a wet bar was extravagant... but it's surprising how much use you can get out of it. Dee-Ann watches the drinkmaking.
How's Walter?
He couldn't be happier. He has everything he ever dreamed of. 61.
And so do you! Fabulous. Dee-Ann smiles archly. She glances away -- and notices Margaret's STUDIO, the door half-open.
Oh, is that your studio? Margaret turns -- and gasps.
No --! You can't go in --
I just want a peek. See what the workspace of a wildly successful artist looks like --
Dee-Ann, please! STOP -- Margaret rushes to block her -- but Dee-Ann pushes open t door, revealing...

A room full of MDHs and Keanes. Dee-Ann stops, puzzled. She glances at Margaret -- who ha turned white as a ghost. Immensely curious, Dee-Ann slowly enters. She peers aroun the two styles of paintings... A strained silence. Finally, Margaret whispers.

W-Walter paints in here too. Hmm. Dee-Ann walks about, examining the canvases. Then, her ga settles on the Big Eye that Margaret was working on. Below the easel is the wet brush on the open jar of paint Margaret sucks in her breath. Dee-Ann sees this.
Is Walter home?? Margaret has no answer. The two friends look at each other... Dee-Ann waiting... wondering if Margaret is going to lie to her... 62.
When..... SLAM!
Both women startle. FOOTSTEPS. Then... Walter strides in! Margaret's eyes pop. Walter's pop even bigger. He glares at the ladies.
What the hell's going on here?!!
Uh... Dee-Ann was just... she... Margaret trails off. Walter thinks, then SNAPS.

You KNOW I don't like anyone seeing my work before it's done! Walter rushes to the Waif, then for show grabs up the wet brush and quickly starts to "finish" the painting. Suddenly -- an odd expression crosses his face. He eyebal the canvas, realizing he doesn't know what to do. A furtive glance. Then, unbowed, he hastily dips the brus and slaps a little black onto the shaded background. Walter spins, victorious.
There!
The three sit silently, tension thick, sipping gin fizzes Nobody speaks. Walter finishes his drink and pours a fresh one.
They are drunk and SCREAMING. Walter pushes Dee-Ann out t door. 63.
You and your whole non-representational crowd are FRAUDS!!
SHUT UP! You're so full of shit, Walter!
Get outta my house! My big house!
Go back to sellin' your coat hanger sculptures on Fisherman's Wharf!
Fuck you! Dee-Ann staggers outside, then hops in her car.
Dee-Ann GUNS the engine and squeals away. The car peels d the very long driveway. Margaret and Walter watch the car disappear into the dist Without looking over, Walter speaks.
I don't want her ever invited here again. Margaret nods, terribly sad.
I won't.
Margaret and Walter lie in bed, awake. Arms crossed. Unspeaking.
Margaret and 13-YEAR-OLD JANE play on the lawn with the poodle. Jane laughs as the dog chases in circles.
Go, Rembrandt! Get the ball! She tumbles, and Rembrandt licks her ear. She giggles.
Okay, honey. I have to go work. 64.
Can I come? (an awkward silence) No. I can never come. No! I shouldn't even ask. Jane glares glumly. Margaret peers hopelessly at her daughter... then goes in
Margaret strolls to her studio. WE SEE the poodle scamper behind her on its cute little legs. She enters the
Margaret doesn't notice the tiny dog follow her in. She L the door, then turns -- surprised.
Where did you appear from? Didn't you hear? No visitors! Rembrandt wags his tail, his little eyes bright. Margaret peers.

Is this what it's come to? You're the only living soul I can tell my secret? (she lowers her voice) Well -- I painted them all! (she shudders with release) It's TRUE! I did every single one -- She gestures, then catches sight of a Walter street scene
Well, every one except that street scene.

But I did the rest. Every Big Eye! And nobody will ever know. But YOU. Rembrandt pants and BARKS. Margaret chuckles, then goes to work. She pulls a CURTAIN across the sliding glass door. At her easel, she squirts tube into a well and starts mixing colors. Rembrandt jumps on the couch.
No you don't! It's nice to have company, but that sofa is new. (she pushes him off) Let's find you some carpet to lay on. 65.
Margaret goes over to a CLOSET. Rembrandt follows, curiou
Margaret turns on the bare bulb inside. It's filled with easels... cans... junk...
I think there's a scrap back here... She rummages, sliding the junk aside. In back is a TATTER WOODEN CRATE. Hm?

Well what's this? Margaret swings the bulb closer. The crate is covered wit SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS and international markings. Margaret's interest is piqued. She tugs at the lid, pulli it off. Revealing inside a STACK OF STREET SCENE PAINTING Ten or fifteen of Walter's canvases. Or so it seems.
She peers closer.
The top painting is a typical Parisian street scene: Cobb stones, a man carrying baguettes, an old lady selling ros But down in the bottom corner is the signature: "S. CENIC

She sucks in her breath, shocked. She examines the painti Then, she hurriedly grabs the next canvas. It's another sunlit scene: A quaint Parisian cafe, a man playing accor and in the bottom right corner... the signature: "S. CENI WHAT?! Margaret grabs the next canvas. "S. CENIC" The next canvas. The next canvas! They all are signed "S. CENIC" Margaret starts hyperventilating. 66.
She thinks, then suddenly bolts from the closet.

Margaret races, rushing up to Walter's painted street sce hung on the wall. We PUSH IN TIGHT, as she shoves her fac to the canvas, so close we can see the brushstrokes -- As we MOVE IN TO THE SIGNATURE. Simply, "W. KEANE" Margaret's face is flushed. She gazes at the name... then rushes back to her work area. She manically hunts: Brushe tubes, rags -- and an EXACTO KNIFE. Ah! She runs back to Walter's painting. Heart pounding, s grazes the knife up against the signature, then DIGS. And -- the "W. KEANE" flecks off. Revealing... underneath the name "S. CENIC"
She trembles, overcome. Music SWELLS. Her eyes spin back

Walter painting at the Palace of Fine Arts. His canvas is blank. Walter in the apartment, signing his name to a finished p Walter spattering paint on his clothes. Walter the day we met him. He shows off a rack of finishe paintings at the Sunday Art Show.
She collapses.
A grandfather clock says 10:15. Margaret sits gloomily, staring at the clock. Clutching a drink.

2:30 a.m. Margaret still stares at the clock. She's stewi Suddenly, keys in the door. Walter swings in, tanked and of life. He skids across the marble, humming to himself - when -- he's startled by his wife. He jerks. 67.
M-Maggie! What're you doin' up? Margaret glares. Not speaking. He shrugs.

I had a helluva night. Worked three or four clubs. (he winks, loosey-goosey) Stumbled onto some hot gossip: Madame Chiang Kai-shek is coming to town! Straight from Taipei! I think we should present her with a painting -- get Dick to flack it...
Or the heck with Dick. I met a new guy at UPI...
Maybe you should give her one of your street scenes.
You think? I dunno -- I thought you could whip off a doodle of Chinatown. With a cute little kid, sort of a big- eyed slanty-eyed thing... Margaret's anger is raging. She glares, steely.
No, Walter. She's a dignitary. Doesn't she deserve a piece that comes straight from you?
From your experience???
Yeah? Maybe you're right. She probably doesn't have a Parisian street scene hanging in her palace. Margaret nods, as if they've settled something. She turns walk away -- then suddenly SPINS.
Unless Madame Chiang Kai-shek already has a Cenic.
He freezes up. Suddenly sober, smacked to reality. 68.
"Cenic"...? Uh, what's that? Margaret stares, eyes sharp.
Cenic is the name of the artist who did all your early paintings.

Huhhh? (spinning his lie) Urgh... oh! CENIC! (he laughs crazily) Cenic was my nickname in Paris! All my art school pals loved my scenic views, so they called me "Scenic"! But since those Frogs can't pronounce a hard "e," I became "Cenic." He looks up at her hopefully. But she shakes her head.
The more you lie, the smaller you seem.
(unyielding, scrambling) How DARE you accuse me of lying! I'm proud of my early Cenics!
Then why do you paint over the name? Walter gasps, floored. Margaret bores in.
A bit of advice: Don't use a water- base over an oil. It flecks off. Walter cowers.
You sound crazy! For God's sake. You've... you've SEEN me paint!!!!
No, I haven't.
I always thought I had... but it's some kind of... mirage. From a distance you look like a painter, but up close... there's nothing there. 69.
All life drains from his face. His eyes go glazed. He spe mechanically. Tiredly...
I studied art in Paris. I went to school at the Beaux-Arts. The Grand Chaumiere. I spent hours in the Louvre, gazing at the greatness of the Masters...
Walter? He turns. She winces, pained.
Have you even been to Paris? Walter blanches. He shakes, broken up. He looks away, then staggers to a chair. He falls into it Trembling. Not able to look her in the eye...
I wanted... I so wanted to be an artist. But -- it just never turned out good. Margaret stares, seething. Then, without comment, she storms away. She SLAMS the doo shut. BANG! Walter doesn't move.
Margaret makes Jane breakfast, scrambling up eggs. Jane glances over her shoulder -- and notices Walter in t living room, asleep on the couch. An awkward pause. Jane says nothing.

Margaret is making the bed. Straightening the pillows. In the b.g., Walter silently creeps into view. Shamefully standing in the doorway. Not speaking... Margaret knows he's there, but doesn't acknowledge his presence. Finally, without making eye contact -- 70.
I don't want you sleeping in this room any longer. I -- I can't keep living these lies.
There's three extra bedrooms. Go pick one. He nods.

Margaret sits, unmoving, trapped in the big house. Outsid JAPANESE GARDENER trims the hedges. Margaret stares at the walls, a smothering Walter Hall of Fame: Framed magazine articles on Walter, smugly posed wi the Waifs. She swallows, then gently opens a dresser drawer. Inside an ORIGINAL WAIF from long ago. A small oil of Jane, when was a toddler. Margaret stares... and then her face slowly crumbles.
Margaret huddles with a SKETCHPAD. Rembrandt is at her fe She's drawing. She looks up, as Walter anxiously enters. He's holding a drink. He clears his throat.
What are you working on?
A new MDH. Something for me. It's about a woman trapped in an uncaring world. I call it, "Escape." Walter bites his lip, afraid to talk.
I figured out a solution to our problems.
What?
Teach me.
Show me your tricks. Then you can pass off the Waifs, and we won't be lying anymore. She looks up in disbelief. 71.
And then -- YOU'LL paint them?
Sure! Why not?
Walter, this isn't paint-by-numbers! You think it's easy?! It took me years to learn --
Y-you're right!
But you know me! I'm a quick study. And I've got the basics... He trails off, unsure where this is going. Trying to rouse her, Walter rushes to an easel and throws blank canvas. She eyeballs him.

If you knew the basics, you wouldn't be at the easel. You have to sketch it first! Walter tightens, feeling stupid. He lets go of the canvas Margaret stares, deciding. Then, she tosses him a PAD. Walter catches it. Slowly, he crosses over...
They peer at each other, like a Mexican standoff. Then, h nervously picks up a pencil.
So...? What's first?
I dunno. You tell me. You're the creator. He frowns.
It's a -- Keane.
Oh, a Keane! How witty.
You know, when we met all those years ago, I never would've imagined in my wildest dreams that one day -- 72.

YEAH YEAH! Point taken. I'm standing here naked and humiliated in front of you. Look... can we just do a crying child? She gazes at him. Fingering her pencil... Trying to jump-start things, he starts to draw a circle -
How old is the subject?
Huh? C'mon, it's a head --
It matters! A young child's head is round. An older child's head is oval! He feels pressured. Hand shaking, he draws a crooked circ
The child is this old!
You're trying to make this difficult --
NO I'M NOT! Every line is a decision!
It's easy to talk about art, but it's not easy to MAKE art!!

Margaret easily outlines a head, then two circles for eye Walter tries copying, but his eyes are misshapen. Again, Walter copies, but he's wobbly. Angry, he scratche out. Margaret tries to help, guiding his hand. Insulted, he pu her off. He CRUMPLES the page. NEW TACTIC: Walter grabs her sketch. He puts it on a LIGH TABLE. Despairing, he starts to trace it..
Walter finally paints. We can't see the canvas, but he's meticulous. His expression quite earnest. He adds a final flourish... and then... a flicker of pride crosses his fa He smiles. 73.

We slowly MOVE AROUND... to REVEAL HIS PAINTING. And... it's... absolutely dreadful. Kindergarten quality. Walter stares. Then, he furtively glances at Margaret's work. Comparing. The realization slowly sinks in. He has no ability. A sadness swells into fury... and suddenly Walter GRABS H CANVAS and SMASHES IT AGAINST THE EASEL. CRASH!! The canv SHREDS. The frame blasts into pieces! Walter spins. He glares at one of Margaret's finished Waifs... then explodes, even more enraged. HE PICKS UP
